titleStmt.title: Mapping Complementary Features of Cross-Species Structural Connectivity to Construct Realistic "Virtual Brains"

analytic.title: Mapping Complementary Features of Cross-Species Structural Connectivity to Construct Realistic "Virtual Brains"

biblStruct.note: Received for publication 14 September 2015; Revised 8 November 2016; Accepted 20 December 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Modern systems neuroscience increasingly leans on large-scale multi-lab neuroinformatics initiatives to provide necessary capacity for biologically realistic modeling of primate whole-brain activity.
Here, we present a framework to assemble primate brain's biologically plausible anatomical backbone for such modeling initiatives.
In this framework, structural connectivity is determined by adding complementary information from invasive macaque axonal tract tracing and non-invasive human diffusion tensor imaging.
Both modalities are combined by means of available interspecies

Whole-brain computational modeling tools in neuroscience posit a number of challenges, one of which is the provision of a biologically plausible anatomical substrate [Deco et al., 2011;Honey et al., 2007].

Specifically, spatially discrete neural mass models require realistic structural parameters such as connectivity strength, axonal myelination, and conduction velocity to ensure proper computation of delays and emerging activity patterns [Stefanescu and Jirsa, 2008].
In turn, spatially continuous neural field models require realistic spatial mapping of extended brain regions on top of the aforementioned neural mass model [Bojak et al., 2010].

These requirements arise from multiple sources of evidence confirming a direct yet implicit link between brain structure and function, originating from the early studies of Camillo Golgi, Santiago Ram on y Cajal, and Charles Scott Sherrington, and continuing to be supported by a number of modern neuroimaging studies [Berlucchi, 1999;Glasser et al., 2016;Hagmann et al., 2010;Margulies et al., 2016;Reid et al., 2016;Saggio et al., 2016;Shen et al., 2012;Zimmermann et al., 2016].
In humans, anatomical pathways are typically modeled by diffusion MRI (dMRI) data.

Inclusion of additional modalities, such as more direct invasive axonal tract tracing from non-human primates, helps resolve inherent issues with dMRI directionality, fiber crossings, and existence or absence of actual connections as such.

A particularly remarkable added value of tract tracing connectivity is not only provision of information on existent connectivity, but information on regional pairs for which absence of connectivity is explicitly confirmed.

Recent direct comparisons between dMRI and tract tracing suggested certain similarities between connectivity datasets derived from both modalities, yet these similarities appear to be biased by regional specificity, interspecies differences, and other possible confounding factors [Goulas et al., 2014;Reid et al., 2016].
We, therefore, instead of comparing the two modalities, put our efforts to derive common evidence from both datasets using a newly developed probabilistic approach.
We describe this approach in the context of The Virtual Brain (TVB) modeling initiative [Ritter et al., 2013;Sanz-Leon et al., 2013;Schirner et al., 2015;Woodman et al., 2014].
To provide a full-scale structural backbone for this initiative, we derived cortical, thalamic and basal ganglia connectivity maps in both the macaque and human brain.

Macroscopic connectivity between pertaining regions was queried from a non-human primate tract tracing database [Bakker et al., 2012;Stephan et al., 2001] and human DTI data were acquired and processed using a previously described paradigm [Zalesky and Fornito, 2009].
To arrange data from both modalities in human brain space, we used available registration and deformation tools [Mazziotta et al., 1995;Tadel et al., 2011;Van Essen et al., 2012].

We registered axonal tract tracing data from the CoCoMac database (http://cocomac.g-node.org) to the F99 macaque brain [Van Essen et al., 2012] and subsequently deformed to the human MNI template [Lyttelton et al., 2007;Mazziotta et al., 1995] using the tool Computerized Anatomical Reconstruction and Editing Toolkit (CARET; http://www.nitrc.
org/projects/caret).
The initial connectivity matrix was derived from CoCoMac using algebraic and machine learning techniques.
The cortical regions of interest (ROI) map, suitable for various primate species (Regional Map [RM]), was adapted from [K€ otter and Wanke, 2005].
Subsequently, basal ganglia and thalamic [Behrens et al., 2003] ROIs were included.
These ROIs were used for seeding the DTI data acquired from 10 healthy subjects, and fiber tracking was performed using a previous technique [Zalesky and Fornito, 2009].

Derivation of evidence from a combined dataset of DTI and tract tracing connectivity was done using a Bayesian approach we devised following the logical assumption that tract lengths and counts are both distributed normally, and differently for absent and present CoCoMac connectivity.
The CoCoMac database [Bakker et al., 2012;Stephan et al., 2001] is a neuroinformatics resource for collation of axonal tract tracing data on a non-human primate brain.

Recently, the original online database interface [K€ otter, 2004] was redeveloped [Bakker et al., 2012], allowing greater flexibility in data collation and retrieval, providing a number of convenience services (http://cocomac.g-node.org/cocomac2/
services/) and an intuitive visualization tool Scalable Brain Atlas [Bakker et al., 2015] (http://scalablebrainatlas.incf.
org), a more lightweight, browser-based and upgraded version of the CP3D tool [Bezgin et al., 2009] (http://www.
nitrc.org/projects/cp3d/).

Objective Relational Transformation (ORT) is an algebraic approach to fill gaps in CoCoMac by means of mapping data between various brain atlases using statements of spatial relationships derived from tract-tracing and cytoarchitecture literature [Stephan et al., 2000].
Recently, the original ORT was redeveloped to adapt to vastly increasing dataset sizes [Bakker et al., 2012].

div.head: CARET; Spatial Cortical ROIs and Deformations

p.s: The tool CARET [Van Essen et al., 2012] was designed by the Van Essen lab to register structural and functional data on cortical surfaces including human, nonhuman primates, and rodents.
The tool provides landmark-based deformation approaches, including interspecies registration [Orban et al., 2004;Van Essen and Dierker, 2007].
We used the latter approach to deform a primate species independent RM (see next subsection) from the macaque F99 template to the human MNI surface [Lyttelton et al., 2007].
The RM was originally proposed by K€ otter and Wanke [2005] as a possible solution to resolve conflicts between parcellations in different primate (including human) species.
As such, RM captures the most consistent cytoarchitectonic, topographic, or functionally defined regions appearing in the variety of primate species, in the least ambiguous way possible.
RM was manually drawn on the macaque F99 template [Bezgin et al., 2012[Bezgin et al., , 2008] ] (see Supporting Information Fig. 1).

In this study, we have deformed it to both surface-and volume-based MNI representations [Lyttelton et al., 2007;Mazziotta et al., 1995] using a functional/cytoarchitectonic landmark-based registration [Orban et al., 2004].

div.head: Subcortical ROIs and Associated Tracing Data

p.s: Besides a full-cortex RM parcellation, we additionally included several thalamic nuclei and related basal ganglia circuits.

While CoCoMac includes a hierarchically organized variety of thalamic nuclei [Burton and Jones, 1976;Olszewski, 1952], we aimed to combine them into several groups to ensure a multi-voxel representation for each group of nuclei, whereas smaller parcellation via individual nuclei could have a sub-voxel size.
This subdivision included three groups of nuclei per hemisphere, based on the predominant cortical targets [Behrens et al., 2003].

An additional parcellation involved two groups of nuclei per hemisphere on the basis of their functional and topographic properties: relay (anterior and ventral nuclei) and association (posterior and dorsal nuclei) groups.
Basal ganglia involved caudate nucleus, putamen, nucleus accumbens, and globus pallidus.
See Supporting Information Text 1 for details.

Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) and gradient recalled echo (GRE) data were acquired for nine healthy subjects (age between 18 and 30 years, mean 24.33 1/2 3.8 years, 5 females, 4 males) at Berlin Center for Advanced Imaging, Charit e University Medicine, Berlin, Germany.
In addition, for each participant, anatomical T1-weighted and T2-weighted scans were acquired directly before the DTI and GRE recordings.
MRI was performed using a 3 Tesla Siemens Trim Trio MR scanner and a 12-channel Siemens head coil.
Specifications for the used sequences can be found in [Ritter et al., 2010].

Each scan session started with a localizer sequence (repetition time [TR]: 20 ms, echo time [TE]: 5 ms, 3 slices (8 mm), voxel size: 1.9 3 1.5 3 8.0 mm, flip angle [FA]: 408, field of view [FoV]: 280 mm, 192 matrix).

For each participant, anatomical T1-weighted scans (MPRAGE, TR: 1,900 ms, TE: 2.25 ms, 192 sagittal slices (1.0 mm), voxel size: 1 3 1 3 1 mm, FA: 98, FoV: 256 mm, 256 matrix as well as T2-weighted scans (2d turbo spin-echo sequence, turbo factor 7, TR: 2,640 ms, TE1: 11 ms, TE2: 89 ms, 48 slices (3.0 mm), voxel size: 0.9 3 0.9 3 3 mm, FA: 1508, FoV: 220 mm, 256 matrix were done.

DTI data (twice-refocused spin echo diffusion preparation; 64 different diffusion directions, b-value 1,000 s/mm 2 , one b0 image recorded, no automatic distortion correction, TR 7,500 ms, TE 86 ms, 61 transversal slices (2.0 mm), voxel size 2.3 3 2.3 3 2.3 mm, FoV 220 mm, PAT: GRAPPA, phase partial fourier: 6/8, 96 matrix and GRE field maps (TR 674 ms, TE1 5.09 ms, TE2 7.55 ms, 61 transversal slices (2.3 mm), FA 608, FoV 220 mm, 96 matrix, Phase encoding direction R L) were measured directly after the anatomical scans.
On extraction of gradient vectors and values (known as b-table) using MRTrix (http://www.nitrc.org/projects/
mrtrix/), diffusion-weighted MRI (dw-MRI) data were pre-processed using FreeSurfer (http://freesurfer.net/).

Besides motion correction and eddy current correction, the b0 image was linearly registered (6 degrees of freedom) to the subject's anatomical T1-weighted image and the resulting registration rule was stored for later use.
We transformed the high-resolution mask volumes from the anatomical space to the subject's diffusion space, to further use it for fiber tracking.

The cortical (RM, see Regional Map section) and subcortical (basal ganglia and thalamus, see Subcortical ROIs and Associated Tracing Data section) parcellations (denoted RM 1 SubCtx) were resampled into diffusion space, one time using the original 1 mm isotropic voxel size (for subvoxel seeding) and one time matching that of our dw-MRI data, that is, 2.3 mm isotropic voxel size.
During MRTrix pre-processing diffusion tensor images that store the diffusion tensor (i.e., the diffusion ellipsoid) for each voxel location were computed.
Based on that, a fractional anisotropy (FA), mean diffusivity (MD) and an eigenvector map were computed and masked by the binary white matter (WM) mask created previously.
For subsequent fiber-response function estimation, a mask containing high-anisotropy voxels was computed.
To resolve crossing pathways, fibers were prolonged by using a probabilistic tracking approach as provided by MRTrix.
It is based on a constrained spherical deconvolution that computes the fiber orientation description function for each image voxel [Tournier et al., 2004].
To exclude spurious tracks, three types of masks were used to constrain tracking: seeding-, target-and stop-masks.
To restrict track-prolongation to WM, a WM-mask that contains the union of GM-WMinterface and cortical WM voxels was defined as a global stop mask for tracking.

To address several confounds in the estimation of connection strengths (information transmission capacities), a new seeding and fiber aggregation strategy was used developed for this pipeline, which involved fiber tracking being constrained by axonal tract tracing connectivity (see Probabilistic Model to Combine Evidence from Invasive Tracing and DTI Data section for the constraint description).
In combination with a new aggregation scheme, the pipeline involved an appropriate selection of seed voxels and controlling for the number of generated tracks in each seed voxel.
Instead of using every WM voxel, tracks were initiated from GM-WM-interface voxels and a fixed number of tracks were generated for each seed-voxel.
As a gray matter (GM) parcellation-based aggregation was performed, each seed-mask was associated with a ROI of the GM atlas.
Along with seeding-masks, complementary target-masks were defined specifying terminal RM 1 SubCtx regions for each track that was initiated in a specific seed voxel.

The fiber tracking procedure was based on previous work [Zalesky and Fornito, 2009], in which an undirected graph of brain WM voxels was created, and edges were added to the graph if the angle between the principal eigenvectors of two adjacent voxels in a 26-voxel neighborhood was less than a predefined curvature threshold (L path /L straight < 10).

A globally optimal solution was found by identifying link-disjoint shortest paths between predefined source and sink ROIs, represented by the RM 1 SubCtx map, and these paths formed the basis of the reconstructed WM pathways.
At each iteration of the procedure, source and sink voxels were selected by randomly sampling from the ROIs, and the number of samples was fixed at twice the number of voxels in the largest ROI.
The distance and number of paths found to connect each source-sink voxel pair was calculated.
The number of such paths is henceforth referred to as capacity.
In addition, an image of the reconstructed pathway was generated in which the value of each voxel represented the number of paths found to traverse that voxel.

The capacity measures that we derived between each pair of regions were intended to estimate the strength of the influence that one region exerts over another, that is, their structural connectivity (SC).
To improve existing methods for capacities estimation, the approach makes use of several assumptions with regard to seed-ROI selection, tracking, and aggregation of generated tracks.

To account for other useful streamline properties, additional two capacity metrics were used and involved number of paths multiplied by FA, and number of paths multiplied by inverse MD, normalized by the maximum value (henceforth referred to as inverse adjusted MD, or MD InvAdj .

div.head: Probabilistic Model to Combine Evidence from Invasive Tracing and DTI Data

p.s: For combining evidence from CoCoMac and DTI connectivity, we devised a probabilistic approach using CoCo-Mac connectivity as a prior, and likelihood functions of tract lengths and capacities from DTI data:

div.formula: P Kj t l ; t c f g ð Þ 5 P t l ; t c f gjK ð ÞP K ð Þ P j2K P t l ; t c f gjj ð Þ P j ð Þ (1)

p.s: where t l ; t c f g are ordered pairs of values representing length and capacity for a given set of tracts appearing in one of two given categories j signifying evidence of presence (denoted as Exis) or evidence of absence (abbreviated as EoA) of CoCoMac connectivity (i.e., j 2 K5
Exis; EoA f g ).
P K ð Þ is a prior representing the probability of existence of a CoCoMac connection, assumed to be uniform and hence set to 0.5.

The first term in the numerator of the right side of the equation is a likelihood of a DTI tract to have a specific length and capacity given its presence or absence in CoCoMac; this term is represented as a bivariate Gaussian distribution.
Hence, for each j 2 K we have:

div.formula: P t l ; t c f gjK ð Þ 5 1 2pr t l r tc e 2 t l 2l t l ð Þ 2 =2r 2 t l 1 tc2l tc ð Þ 2 =2r 2 tc h i (2)

p.s: where the left term is the likelihood of tract length t l and tract capacity t c given CoCoMac connectivity, l and r are corresponding means and covariance matrices, respectively-separately for each of the connection classes j 2 K.

As outlined in section Empirical DTI data processing, while tract lengths were kept as fixed values, several measures were used under the term capacity: (1) overall tract counts, (2) FA multiplied by tract counts, and (3) inverse adjusted MD (MD InvAdj ) multiplied by tract counts.
We have generated analogous models for a sample of randomized tract tracing connectivity matrices (N 5 1,000).

Randomization was performed with preserved degree distribution [see Maslov and Sneppen, 2002;Rubinov and Sporns, 2010] and involved binarization such that each matrix entry included 0 in case of confirmed absence of connection (EoA), and 1 otherwise.
During the process of random matrix generation, the reassignment of connection classes was preserved to identify which of the nonzero entries of a resulting matrix signified confirmed existing

TVB is a large-scale initiative to model the primate brain from a mean field theory perspective [Kringelbach et al., 2015;Ritter et al., 2013;Roy et al., 2014;Sanz-Leon et al., 2013;Woodman et al., 2014].

As such, it provides an interactive interface to use biophysical mean field models, such as Wilson-Cowan [Wilson and Cowan, 1972], Jansen-Rit [Jansen and Rit, 1995], or Stefanescu-Jirsa [Stefanescu and Jirsa, 2008] models.
As an input, the interface takes connectivity matrices with strength/capacity values, connection lengths to calculate conduction delays.

For more advanced modeling purposes, one can include not only ROI represented by a set of sparse network nodes but also a set of cortical mesh nodes and patches, so that the cortical sheet can be represented as a spatial continuum, or a "neural field."

To model responses as observed in electroencephalography (EEG) or magnetoencephalography (MEG) on a sensor level, it may be required to provide surfaces not only representing cortex, but also head and skull representations.

A fully automated pipeline exists to extract individual structural connectomes, cortical triangulations, parcellations, lead field matrices, and functional connectomes from multimodal imaging data to construct personalized Virtual Brains as a basis for individualized TVB simulations [Schirner et al., 2015].
Following the F99-MNI deformation, we obtained the human cortical parcellation mask which included 82 regions covering the entire cortex.
For alternative analysis options, the surface was also converted to a volumetric representation by a 1-mm extrusion.
Additional surfaces of head, inner and outer skull, as well as MEG sensor locations were obtained from Brainstorm [Tadel et al., 2011].
These components are summarized in Figure 1.
Figure 2 depicts the DTI fiber tracking procedure described in section Empirical DTI data processing and an
To include thalamus in our brain map, we have adopted a previous approach [Behrens et al., 2003].

In that study, thalamus was represented by seven clusters of nuclei, each of which has a distinctive pattern of connectivity with cerebral cortex (Fig 3, see Supporting Information Table 4 for full names of the nuclei).
As such, the original approach identified clusters with stronger connectivity to each given cortical lobe.
We adapted this approach and reduced the number of clusters to 3 to ensure super-voxel resolution.
For that, we grouped small clusters displaying strongest connectivity to parietal and occipital cortices, to one large cluster (Fig. 3A-D).
The resulting density of the thalamocortical network was 0.73 (compare to the whole brain average of 0.43, see Connectivity Matrices section).
We also devised an alternative thalamic nuclei grouping scheme, which was dictated by a general functional specialization of thalamus-namely, into relay and association groups (Fig. 3E).

Both representations are provided as two alternative partitioning schemes for TVB; see associated connectivity matrices in Supporting Information Tables 2 and 3, and Table S4 for abbreviations of the nuclei.
The resulting non-symmetric SC matrix from CoCoMac (Fig. 4, bottom left) includes 96 regions in both hemispheres (41 1 41 cortical regions, 3 1 3 thalamic subdivisions and 4 1 4 basal ganglia).

To abide by the citation policy of CoCoMac, we provide citations to the original publications that contributed at least 10 tracer injections to the matrix shown in Figure 4, bottom left (See also Supporting Information Text 2).
The average matrix density is 0.43 (0.64 within each hemisphere and 0.17 between hemispheres); cortico-cortical matrix density is 0.5 (0.72 within hemispheres and 0.29 between hemispheres).
One-subject instance of DTI tract counts and tract length are depicted in Figure 4, top right and bottom left.
Please refer to Supporting Information Table 1 for the region names, and Supporting Information Table 2 for the actual matrix data.
For cortical connectivity data within hemispheres, we derived the likelihood parameters using bivariate Gaussian distributions obtained from pairs of distance and capacity values, using Eq.
Capacity values were of (1) those involving total tract counts, (2) FA multiplied by tract counts, and (3) inverse adjusted MD multiplied by tract counts.

Posterior probability density functions (PDFs) (Fig. 5D) obtained using formula (1) were used to evaluate confirmed (absence of) connectivity in CoCoMac, which served as an accuracy estimate (Fig. 5E); further, these PDFs were used to predict connectivity in the case of total absence of evidence in CoCoMac.

Consistency of the predictions across subjects (no less than 60% of subjects, no less than 80% of subjects, all subjects) derived by the latter measure served as a reproducibility measure for this approach (Fig. 5F).
Accuracy estimates across different sample sizes were generally the highest for FA*tract_counts (83% for max-2std; Fig. 5E, Table I).
Average probability values from posterior PDF were increasingly higher for correct than incorrect estimates (Table I).
By contrast, the highest total reproducibility was achieved with MD InvAdj *tract_counts (61% vs. 47% with other measures; Fig. 5F).
To validate the use of CoCoMac-derived tract tracing connectivity to constrain DTI data, we have performed analyses on a sample of randomized tract tracing matrices (N 5 1,000).
For each such matrix, a model as described in formulae ( 1) and (2) was computed.

Figure 6 shows the results of this validation: (a) likelihood PDFs feature greater distances between Exis and EoA means (cf., the means of distributions shown in Fig. 5B,C) and smaller standard deviations for the original network than for randomized sample, entailing a poorer tessellation of the parameter space for random matrices; (b) global maxima of the posterior PDF are larger for the original network than for random sample; (c) mean posterior probability is higher for true positives and lower for false positives in the original network than in its randomized counterparts; (d) predictive power for matrix entries with no connectivity evidence (absence of evidence, AoE) is stronger for the original network than for random sample (Fig. 6).
Differences between the original matrix metrics and their randomized counterpart outputs were significant along all dimensions (P 5 0, one-sample t-test).
In this study, we proposed and implemented a framework of an anatomical backbone for TVB and related generative modeling initiatives.
(1) We have represented a primate species independent brain map on a macaque cortical surface and deformed it to surface-and volume-based human templates.
(2) We have added basal ganglia and thalamic nuclei to the model; two different subdivision schemes for thalamic nuclei were proposed.
(3) For these regions, we obtained a fully connected connectivity matrix from the tract tracing database CoCoMac, which encompassed both hemispheres.

(4) We acquired DTI data from 10 subjects, and processed the data using a recent ROI seeding-based procedure [Zalesky and Fornito, 2009], obtaining such measures as tract length, tract counts, FA and MD.

(5) We devised a probabilistic model to predict connectivity on the basis of tract lengths and counts (in other instances, the latter metric, referred to as capacity, was also multiplied by FA and inverse adjusted MD).
We evaluated the performance of this model on the basis of replicating the existent data (accuracy) Extracting evidence from a combined tracing-DTI dataset.

(A) Tract capacity across all subjects has a weak but significant negative correlation with tract length, with a slight propensity of confirmed CoCoMac connections to have shorter distances than those pairs of regions for which absence of connectivity is confirmed; red dots signify existent connections, blue crosses stand for evidence of absence.

(B,C) Likelihood of tract length and capacity values given the confirmed presence (B) or absence (C) of connectivity in CoCoMac, obtained using Eq. ( 2); (D) posterior probability of connectivity presence and absence given tract length and capacity, derived using Bayes' rule (formula 1); contours demarcate the first quartiles for both distributions.

(E) Accuracy of obtained results: fraction of CoCoMac grades predicted correctly using Bayes' theorem for tract counts, FA*tract_counts, MD InvAdj *tract_counts; the highest accuracy is achieved with FA multiplied by tract counts.

(F) Reproducibility of obtained results: consistency of predictions across at least 60% of subjects, at least 80% of subjects and across all subjects for undefined CoCoMac grades (total absence of evidence); total reproducibility is best achieved with inverse adjusted MD multiplied by tract counts.
[Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com] and consistency in predicting new data (reproducibility).
Accuracy was generally the highest for FA*tract_counts and total reproducibility was the best for MD InvAdj *tract_counts.

( 6) Validation of the model was performed using a sample of randomized matrices by carrying out statistical comparisons of their outcome to the original matrix model, which confirmed the model validity.
A schematic description of overall study concepts is provided in Figure 7.

Recently, there have been a number of efforts to compare different connectivity modalities, including human DTI and macaque tracing datasets, revealing both correspondence and mismatch patterns, featuring large variability across different brain regions albeit suggesting interesting commonalities in the global cortical organization [Goulas et al., 2014;Margulies et al., 2016;Reid et al., 2016].
In the current study, we provided a Bayesian statistics paradigm to derive relevant patterns from both datasets.
Tract length is a better predictor for connectivity than tract capacity, albeit the latter is improved by multiplying FA by tract counts.
Prediction is not affected by switching hemispheres, speaking to the fact that non-human primate lateralization is less prevalent than in humans.
The used brain atlas, RM, provides a reasonable estimate of macaque-human homology-however, the confounding effects still take place.
One of the peculiarities in the RM cortical connection matrix is the noticeably sparse connectivity of dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (PFCdm) in both hemispheres.

Interestingly, several previous resting state MRI studies in macaque reported sparse [Vincent et al., 2010] or even absent [Hutchison et al., 2011;Teichert et al., 2010;Vincent et al., 2007] connectivity associated with this region.
This is in sharp contrast to the human counterpart of this area which appears to be a densely functionally connected part of the default mode network [Raichle et al., 2001].
It may be that the SC of the PFCdm is different in humans and macaques.
Even more scattered and obscure is available information on interhemispheric connectivity.

Most axonal tract tracing studies investigate systems within a given hemisphere, only seldom investigating particular pathways connecting areas with their contralateral counterparts (homotopic connections) or with other regions in the opposite hemisphere (heterotopic connections).

Homotopic connections are generally more abundant and strong, and evidence for their absence exists in greater detail, especially for non-primary sensory/ motor regions [Rouiller et al., 1994;Shen et al., 2015].

For example, there is a confirmed absence of homotopic monosynaptic connections between amygdalae [Demeter et al., 1990] in macaque, whereas strong connectivity for a large number of homologous pairs has been reported (e.g., left and right frontal eye fields [Huerta et al., 1987]; primary and secondary auditory cortices [Hackett et al., 1999]).
The capacity measures derived for each pair of regions are intended to estimate the relative strengths of the influence that regions exert over one another, that is, their SC.

SC is a relative description of coupling that is turned into an absolute description of mutual influence that only exists in the context of a specific model and a coupling function that transforms it into effective connectivity (EC) with respect to the specific local node models that are coupled together.
However, neither SC nor EC can be directly measured by diffusion imaging, and several aspects harden their approximation.
In addition, due to step-wise dispersion of the propagating streamline the probability that a specific track is prolonged decreases as a function of the distance from the seed point.
This creates a bias toward short pathways and pathways that follow the major diffusion directions.

Therefore, the number of found tracks does neither quantify the strength of a connection nor the probability of the existence of a connection but merely reflect the chance that a streamline could propagate along the specific pathway of the tracks [Jones et al., 2013].

To improve existing methods for capacities estimation and to address the aforementioned confounds, we make use of several techniques with regard to seed-ROI selection, tractography and aggregation of generated tracks.
Along with capacities, the pipeline outputs three different SC distance matrices that contain the mean, mode, and median lengths of all tracks that were found between each pair of regions.
Combining evidence from invasive animal axonal tract tracing and human DTI provides better reliability of the results than using each of those measurement modalities alone.
With regard to the probabilistic model proposed in the current study, there are two points to consider.
First, FA*tract_counts seems to be a more accurate predictor of existing CoCoMac connectivity than other measures used as capacity in this study.
A possible explanation is that FA might cause a certain "amplification" of the effects observed within graded connectivity categories (existent connectivity vs. evidence of absence).

Second, a better subject-to-subject reproducibility of information absent from CoCoMac (AoE) was achieved with MD InvAdj *tract_counts, which might point to smoother distribution of values across subjects with an inclusion of MD InvAdj as a scaling factor.
The prior in our model was set to a fixed value of 0.5, meaning that occurrences of presence or absence of connectivity were considered equally likely.

This might not necessarily be the case for the RM parcellation with a remarkably high connectivity density (see Thalamic Nuclei and Their Connectivity section and Connectivity Matrices section), but it appears as a fair assumption considering generalizations of this model to include finer parcellations with remarkably sparser connectivity (see Bezgin et al., [2012] for a discussion on dependence between granularity and sparseness).

To establish a granularity-sensitive prior on connectivity, one might need to test large samples of data and rest on assumptions about distributions which would fit a given model best in regard to its accuracy and reproducibility [Yourganov et al., 2014].

Additionally, considering an informative prior with a fully represented PDF would be to a great extent complicated by the fact that CoCoMac is a textual literature database with no information on tract length or capacity.

Indeed, the former could be approximated with straight-line or geodesic distances between areas, while qualitative connectivity strength grades (i.e., weak, moderate, and strong, see Fig. 4) could be used to approximate the latter.
However, given the current data availability, biases introduced by such approach could lead to largely unpredictable outcomes.
One might even consider a reverse path to the approach taken here, that is to using information on established DTI tracts as prior and likelihood functions to inform tract tracing data.

However, such model would involve an important conceptual difference to the one proposed in this study: whereas information on DTI tracts lies in a virtually unrestricted continuum (the tracking procedure would find tracts between any pair of ROIs), the tract tracing data are largely categorical in nature, providing explicit information on connection existence or absence.

With regard to the utility of the presented model in the TVB domain, it is important to mention that several previous studies already utilized RM and associated CoCoMac connectivity in biophysical simulations [Knock et al., 2009;Ritter et al., 2013].

In the study by Knock et al. [2009], the advantage of using a biologically plausible connectivity backbone in simulations is emphasized, suggesting that underlying structural substrate is essential for the model output.
Ritter et al. [2013] combined DTI capacity and distance data with CoCoMac directionality information.
They compared their model output to empirical data, providing another set of evidence suggesting the importance of the anatomically and physiologically plausible constraints on biophysical modeling.

Embedding multimodal anatomical data using probabilistic approaches such as the one presented here offers additional advantages of maximizing connectivity evidence, which will be substantiated in upcoming simulation studies using the presented multimodal structural model.
Multimodal Structural Connectivity for Realistic Virtual Brains r r 2083 r connection (Exis), and which of them represented total absence of evidence (AoE) in the new (random matrix) assignment.

Various surfaces provided for mean field modeling in TVB.

[Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]
Figure 3. Adaptation of thalamic map to achieve super-voxel resolution.

(A) Hierarchical representation of thalamic regions involved; nuclei are grouped by predominant connectivity to frontal (F), occipitopariental (OP) and temporal (T) cortical targets (see Supporting Information Table S4 for the full names of the nuclei); (B) reduction of the occipitoparietal thalamic sources into one group for better spatial consistency; (C) cortical map of corresponding thalamic targets as shown in A; (D) original depiction of thalamic subdivisions in [Behrens et al., 2003]; five regions with corresponding colors targeting primarily the occipitoparietal cortex are reduced into one region as shown in B; left: coronal view, right: sagittal view.
(E) An alternative subdivision of thalamus into relay (bottom) and association (top) nuclei.
For interpretational convenience, the color coding corresponds to the scheme depicted in (A).
[Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]
Figure 4. Axonal tract tracing and DTI matrices from a single subject.
Top left: average tract length for each region pair.
All values range from white being the lowest to black being the highest.
Top right: tract counts resulting from the seeding procedure.
Bottom left: Regional Map (RM) cortical matrix obtained from CoCoMac for both hemispheres, combined with several basal ganglia and thalamic nuclei.
[Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]
Figure 5.
Figure 6.
Evaluation of the proposed probabilistic model.

(A) Comparison of the likelihood functions for the original tract tracing matrix (red star) and a sample of its randomized counterparts (green points); x axis shows differences between the means of Exis and EoA distributions, y axis displays the largest standard deviation among Exis and EoA distributions along the first eigenvector dimension; (B) global maxima in the posterior distributions for Exis (x axis) and EoA (y axis); (C) mean posterior probabilities for correctly (x axis) and incorrectly (y axis) predicted connection grades (Exis vs. EoA), fitted by a quadratic curve; (D) mean posterior probabilities for all AoE region pairs predicted consistently across all subjects (overall prediction, x axis; prediction on the basis of max-2stds of the posterior distribution, y axis).
All differences between original matrix metrics and the corresponding random samples (i.e., red stars and corresponding green point clouds, respectively) yielded P 5 0 (one-sample ttest).
Error bars signify standard deviation along each dimension of a given metric in a sample of randomized matrices.
[Color figure can be viewed at wileyonlinelibrary.com]
Figure 7.
A flowchart describing the concepts in this study.

The main source component to combine DTI and CoCoMac data is the RM parcellation with the included subcortical regions (RM 1 SubCtx); the parcellation is registered on spatial templates, serving to perform the DTI tracking procedure using RM 1 SubCtx map as a stop-mask; tracing data are obtained by querying CoCoMac.
Common evidence is extracted from DTI and tracing data by means the devised probabilistic model.
Both multimodal connectivity and spatial templates are used in a given whole-brain modeling platform, such as TVB.

figure.head: TABLE I . Accuracy in predicting existent CoCoMac evidence using Bayes' probabilistic modeling
figure.label: I

p.s: Accuracy as well as mean probability values obtained from the posterior probability density function (PDF) are shown for prediction performed for maximum PDF assignment minus one, two, and three standard deviations, for both true and false predictions.
In brackets, the corresponding values obtained from single-subject predictions are provided.

Vakorin, Andrew T. Reid, Michael Cheung -helpful discussions; Donna Dierker, John Harwell, David C. Van Essen -help with CARET software and deformation issues.
